item.title: Summary and highlights: The Daily Stoic by Ryan Holiday and Stephen Hanselman - Introduction & Part 1
item.description: Introduction Stoicism is often misunderstood Definition of Stoicism: ancient philosophy that was once one of the most popular civic disciplines in the west Contain some of the greatest wisdom in the history of the world - referring to Meditations by Marcus Aurelius: a series of private notes kept by the Roman Emperor The objective of the book The Daily Stoic is to restore Stoicism to its rightful place as a tool in the pursuit of self-mastery, perseverance and wisdom The philosophy asserts that virtue (the four cardinal virtues of self-control, courage, justice and wisdom) is happiness, and it is our perceptions of things rather than the things themselves that cause most of our trouble It teaches that we can’t control or rely on anything outside of our “reasoned choice” - our ability to choose how we categorise, respond and reorient ourselves to external events Marcus Aurelius, Epictetus and Seneca framed their work revolving Stoicism around a series of exercises in three critical disciplines: The Discipline of Perception - how we see and perceive the world around us The Discipline of Action - the decisions and actions we take and to what end The Discipline of Will - how we deal with the things we cannot change, attain clear and convincing judgement and come to a true understanding of our place in the world By controlling our perceptions, the Stoics tell us we can find mental clarity - in directing our actions properly and justly, we will be effective The ares of great interest to the Stoics all make an appearance here: virtue, mortality, emotions, self-awareness, fortitude, right action, problem solving, acceptance, mental clarity, pragmatism, unbiased thought and duty January - Clarity 01/01: Control and choice

item.title: About
item.description: “The most valuable of all talents is that of never using two words when one will do” I have one goal in the year 2023. I told myself to read more books. But this time I want to make sure that I understand and remember things that I have read. Here I will share summary and highlights of books that I have read, in order for me to revise them whenever I need some inspiration.

item.title: Summary: The Lean Startup by Eric Ries - Introduction
item.description: Summary Writer talks about his own failure building a startup A lesson from both of his successes and failure: its the boring stuff that matters the most - startup success can be engineered by following the right process - can be learned and can be taught Entrepreneurship is a kind of management A new entrepreneur movement built on many previous management and product development idea including: lean manufacturing, design thinking, customer development and agile development Origins of the lean startup Business and marketing functions of a startup are essential as engineering and product development aspect of a startup - deserves an equally rigorous methodology to guide them Author mission: to improve the success rate of new innovative products, worldwide The Lean Startup Method Principles of the lean startup Entrepreneurs are everywhere
